CPEC Commission Report 88-27/Published June 1988 (Proposed Construction of off-campus CC Center in Western Riverside County

October 18th, 2011

Commission Report 88-27 posted on CPEC website is a comprehensive review of the process taken by the MSJC Board of Trustees in 1988 to bring the Menifee Valley Campus to fruition with state capital construction funds.

http://www.cpec.ca.gov/CompleteReports/1988Reports/88-27.pdf

The Proposal

“MSJC requests Board authorization to establish an education center to be called West center at a site adjacent to I-15 near Newport Road approximately midway between Perris, Lake Elsinore and Temecula.  The district has received a donation of fifty acres of land from the John Lusk Company ina new 2,000-acre residential development called Menifee Village.  Initial plans for development call for 27,875 assignable square feet (asf) of academic, administrative and support facilities in three buildings.  To avoid an 18-month budget cycle delay, proposals to fund site development and working drawings for buildings are part of the 1988-89 capital outlay budget proposal reviewed by the Board in July.  (Funding of these projects will not proceed without the approval of the Board of Governors and the subsequent endorsement of CPEC).”

Postsecondary Education Commission/Facilities Review

October 18th, 2011

FYI

http://www.cpec.ca.gov/Reviews/FacilityReview.asp

Facilities Review Process

“In an effort to oversee the facilities projects at earlier stages of development, the Commission refined the review process in 2002.  When a segment enters a discussion to develop a facility, they are required to submit a Preliminary Notice to the Commission, detailing their intent.  The Commission is able to participate in the planning process and offer constructive input before significant time and resources are spent.  The system must submit a Letter of Intent providing an overview of expansion plans, geographical information, budgetary, information.  The third stage is staff review of a Needs Study. The Needs Study should address all Commission review criteria including enrollment projections, detailed budget, and an EIR. Commission staff complete their analysis of the Needs Study and conduct a site visit, then recommend approval or non-approval.”

MSJC Educational Masterplan 2008/(Pg. 9-10, Intro/Background)

“If the District plans to locate new facilities in either the I-15 Corridor or The Pass Service Areas, planning for new centers in the District should take into account these regulations.  Development of the necessary application documents should being as soon as possible. Whether or not districts use locally approved bond money to totally or partially support development, these regulation must be followed if the District wishes to receive State support for operations, staffing or future projects.”

MSJC Ex-chief pressed on towing rotation/PE

October 13th, 2011

http://www.pe.com/local-news/riverside-county/hemet/hemet-headlines-index/20111012-san-jacinto-ex-chief-pressed-on-towing-rotation.ece

“Former Chief Kevin Segawa admitted he lied initially when questioned by Riverside County district attorney’s office investigators about dealing with Pirot’s owner.

“Segawa said he understood he did not have authority to circumvent the procedures, but said his supervisors were aware that vehicle-impound fees collected by Pirot’s were being used for some purchases outside that process.”

Blog:

The unfortunate fact about this issue is that district administration (new superintendent/president) readily defended the chief for months before the DA got involved and district accepted his resignation. The district’s internal investigative report was never released to the board.

FTI/Initial Study and Notice of Preparation (EIR) - San Gorgonio Campus

October 12th, 2011

http://www.msjc.edu/CollegeInformation/Administration/BusinessServices/Pages/Initial-Study-and-.aspx\

“Public Review:  The initial Study is available for a 30-day public review period beginning September 14, 2011, and ending October 14, 2011. Written comments on the proposed project must be received no later than 5 PM on October 14. 2011.”

Blog:

There has been NO notification by administration and/or the MSJC Board Chair on the posting of this document and/or the stated window for public review.  Note:  Page 21 of the document has no district signatures.

To my knowledge the district has not began and/or completed a  ”Needs Assessment Study” for this project. Without such the project would not be eligible for State support for operations, staffing or future projects.  Why not?

MSJC gets $4.2 million grant/PE

October 8th, 2011

http://www.pe.com/local-news/riverside-county/hemet/hemet-headlines-index/20110929-san-jacinto-college-gets-4.2-million-grant.ece

“Federal science and technology funds will allow expansion of the college’s services to students.”

“One goal of the grant-funded programs is to help double the percentage of Hispanic students who earn degress in the STEM field by the 2015-16 academic year.”

“The new grant will pay for three new faculty coordinator positions, provide faculty training and more counseling access for students, and allow the college to organize career fairs and workshops for students and parents.”

Blog:

MSJC has cut hundreds of class sections due to state budget cuts over the past two years reducing FTES served over-cap.  Hopefully this grant will be used for reinstating a percent of those sections in the STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Math) area for increased student access and completion rate.
